questions.question: 1. Internal resistance of an ideal ammeter is

explanations.a: Internal resistance of an ideal ammeter is zero because it is connected in series and should not affect the current.
explanations.b: An infinite resistance would block current, making the ammeter useless.
explanations.c: A small resistance is acceptable in practical ammeters but not ideal ones.
explanations.d: A big resistance would cause significant voltage drop and alter the current.

questions.question: 2. Which instrument has the lowest resistance

explanations.a: An ammeter has very low resistance so it doesn't affect the circuit current. here
explanations.b: A voltmeter must have high resistance to avoid drawing current from the circuit.
explanations.c: A megger is used to measure high resistance, so it has high internal resistance.
explanations.d: A frequency meter's resistance is not its defining characteristic and is typically higher than an ammeter's.

questions.question: 3. Which of the following is not correct?

answers.a: Voltmeter should have a very high resistance
answers.b: An ammeter should have a very low resistance
answers.c: A shunt should have a very low resistance
answers.d: An electronic voltmeter draws appreciable current from source

explanations.a: This is correct because a high-resistance voltmeter minimizes current draw from the circuit.
explanations.b: This is correct since low resistance allows current to flow through the ammeter without obstruction.
explanations.c: This is correct as a shunt diverts current and should not add resistance.
explanations.d: This is incorrect. An electronic voltmeter is designed to draw minimal current.

questions.question: 4. Internal resistance of ideal voltmeter is

explanations.a: A 'big' resistance is good, but an ideal voltmeter has infinite resistance.
explanations.b: A small resistance would allow current to flow and disturb the circuit, which is undesirable.
explanations.c: Correct. Infinite resistance ensures no current is drawn from the circuit.
explanations.d: Zero resistance would short the circuit and is not ideal for a voltmeter.

questions.question: 5. Error of the measurement is the difference between

explanations.a: Correct. Error is defined as the difference between the true value and the measured value. here
explanations.b: Precision is about repeatability, not accuracy. This is incorrect.
explanations.c: Measured value and precision are unrelated in defining error.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Option (a) is the standard definition.
